Award.AwardTitle: NSF INCLUDES: Redefining Potential - the Upstate NY Design and Development Pilot for Diverse Student Populations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The INCLUDES project will build on the Leveraging and Integrating New Knowledge in STEMS (LINKS) framework that was developed at the University of Rochester to target students participating in Upward Bound programs at four institutions that will comprise the Upstate NY Alliance: Cornell University, D'Youville College, Monroe Community College, and the University of Rochester. The project will increase curricular and experiential learning offerings to underserved students by integrating faculty and graduate students into Upward Bound programs. Applying the LINKS framework, educators will learn and develop new means for managing classroom diversity, including ethnicity, language, age, educational background, and other cultural markers that shape the way students learn. The team will develop and disseminate best practices on creating inclusive teaching and research environments. The Upstate NY Alliance will produce a proof of concept model for national scale-up with measurable outcomes for varying populations of at-risk high school students.

The Alliance will strive to translate and further develop the LINKS framework within the context of each of the varied institutional environments, resulting in a more robust model that draws from the strengths of all of the schools with a core focus and range of applications. The project will create a diverse collegial community dedicated to bridging the gap between P-12 and higher education learning environments. It also will implement a clearly-articulated and successful collaboration among the four institutions that will provide multiple opportunities to share best practices, engage in cross-institution dialog, and leverage each member's strengths to enhance and further develop the LINKS framework.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the course of three years we have developed and refined the LINKS Framework, a high impact model of infusing vertical STEM mentoring between 6th through 12th grade First-Generation, Low-Income and/or Underrepresented Minority Students, undergraduates, graduates, staff and faculty at a diverse set of higher education institutions. This project considered our experiences and evaluation data, speaking to the different ways precollege programs at other institutions interact with their STEM faculty and the need for strong collaboration. LINKS provided the connections for these populations to connect and grow, learning from each other.

The framework was successfully implemented at a research one private university, ivy league university, public community college and private teaching and technical college.

Substantial progress was made to increase the STEM exposure of underrepresented students. Over 500 high school students at the partner institutions have had authentic STEM experiences using the LINKS Model. Additionally, over 70 faculty members and 100 graduate students across partner institutions who assisted with increasing STEM exposure, received valuable training and exposure to teaching a diverse population of students and providing growth opportunities for their teaching approach and research.

Monroe Community College (MCC), saw rapid growth in the amount of STEM faculty members who engaged with their pre-college youth. Over the course of the project they saw 300% growth in faculty engagement and tripled their STEM course offering for students. 

Cornell University built upon a strong STEM foundation by creating a summer research day for students from all programs to attend and interact and work with Cornell faculty in courses and labs. 

D’Youville college partnered with their School of Education to formalize a STEM structure for their youth, that increased STEM faculty involvement by 200% and created cross campus partnerships. 

At the University of Rochester, over 60 faculty over two years participated in the program where, offering over 20 courses across all STEM disciplines from biology, chemistry, data science, electrical and computer engineering, bio-medical engineering, photonics and optics.

The LINKS Model has been shared nationally at conferences to provide additional students access to these experiences at their home institutions.

Five high school students presented their research at the 2019 National Society of Black Engineers (NSBE) Annual Convention. One high school student earned the Best Research Poster award at this convention. One high school student had a paper published in a peer-reviewed chemistry journal. This experience was a pivotal learning opportunity for our students, providing exposure on a national level and the experiences needed to be competitive STEM scholars in college.
